The Importance of Tools: Efficiency and Quality
In software development, you never just choose an implementation language alone
what you really choose is a language
the tools and packages accompanying it.
tools supporting an implementation language are an influential factor when software developers select a language.
development tasks that involve writing code. In fact, the chosen language will completely and unambiguously define what statements can be written during fulfillment of these tasks.

However, writing code is only a small part of the total work done on any software project. Other important development activities include generating specifications, planning system architecture, generating test plan
documentation, version control, and configuration management. Also: code
will always occur less frequently than code
, because each line of code will be read more times than it will be written.**
minimal in comparison to time spent on other activities, and Amdahl's L
aw reminds us that the efficiencies gained by speeding up code-writing are limited by the small proportion of the project that actually depends on code-writing.
of a project, developers need to reduce the time required for all the non code-writing tasks. This is why tool support is essential.
For a ubiquitous programming language like Java, it is common to find a wide range of supporting tools covering all aspects of product development. For Java, one easily finds

in each of the following categories: debugging environments, testing frameworks, static analysis tools, fuzzers, automated refactoring tools, documentation generators, visualization kits, internationalization packages, syntax highlighters, cross-referencers, and
of particular relevance to this current paper

With proper use of the relevant tools during each phase of development, a tool-assisted Java project can be completed much more efficiently than a project using nothing more than raw Java source code and a compiler. Additionally, if tool usage also includes various automated tools, we expect a reduction in errors
In the realm of relational database systems, the SQL language is quite easily the single most ubiquitous coding language in existence.

The popularity of SQL in the relational database world is equal to or greater than the popularity of Java in the object-oriented sector. Likewise, an abundance of tools exist for SQL just as is the case with Java. However, the
of tools available for SQL differs greatly from that of Java tools.
ERD modeling and DDL script generation
comparing and synchronizing the content and structure of database tables
auditing permissions on database tables and other objects in the database
performance tuning and performance monitoring tools
In general, we find a very rich set of tools for the administration of a relational database
, and comparatively few tools supporting the act of writing SQL code and

There is a further caveat for tabulating the number of SQL debugging tools currently available: many tools described as SQL debugging tools only target the imperative programming portions of the language, and do not cover debugging of purely relational statements.

How can we create tools that
allow a SQL coder to efficiently produce working SQL code
have confidence that this code runs correctly on all input parameters and all content-states (better word) of the database, not just on a limited test dataset?
Formal verification. For most programs written in languages like C, Java, C#, Python,
is still considered infeasible or prohibitively costly
to formally verify all statements in the program.
The question of whether it is equally infeasible to verify all SQL statements in a program has not been widely addressed. The mathematical basis for the SQL language offers tantalizing
hints that verification could apply to SQL more easily than it applies to C-like languages.
The case for verification of SQL:
Formal verification as commonly used today is based on first-order logic. Much of the work in verifying statements in today's

oriented languages is due to the 'transformation step' (better word) of finding a suitable first-order theory that represents the programming language statements. In the case of relational SQL, however, we already have a fully developed mathematical theory of relational calculus that is expressible

in first-order logic. (relational calculus? relational algebra?) Therefore, the 'transformation step' that is the challenge in other verification settings is completely absent in a setting where the goal is to verify relational SQL. (okay... so i MUST MENTION somewhere about the places where SQL falls short of true mathematical relational concepts)
design by contract - this is the key way we typically relate formal verification to our dev process.
debugging - explain how, in some sense, formal verification of relational SQL might be the closest thing to 'debugging SQL', since the notion of 'stepping through'
really hold up in relational SQL. (rather, sql statements have 'all-at-once' qualities)
testing - Qex is an example of how this approach supports testing
documentation - notations that express ASSUMPTIONS about the code are ALWAYS valuable documentation for future devs/maintainers
refactoring - refactoring can always be done with greater confidence in the presence of some type of test(s). POQ provides this.

the work of the everyday SQL coder. Nonetheless,
goal led to an application of formal verification methods

Before I close this introductory chapter, I want to give a very clear picture of what this assertion-checker does in CONCRETE terms, with at least one small 'teaser' example.
Some of the most closely-related work is similar to my work "in spirit", because the goal is to automate and
methods of bug detection. However, the key difference is that these other projects mostly target the detection of bugs inside the query execution engine of a DBMS
"Query-Aware Test Generation Using a Relational Constraint Solver." http://dx.doi.org/10.1109/ASE.2008.34

Qex. (http://research.microsoft.com/en-us/projects/qex/) this is by far the most closely-related work to my own. However, it still differs in key aspects. Qex is intended to create "unit tests" for queries, with an assumption that the query is working properly right now, but that it might break in the future. Also, Qex still executes the query on actual data in order to decide whether the query behaved properly or not. My work aims to perform checking of assumptions on queries that are NOT KNOWN and NOT ASSUMED to behave as intended, and my work intends to do this checking statically, without executing the SQL code on any actual DBMS.

"Mini Repros" - ( http://doi.acm.org/10.1145/1739041.1739088 ), when there is a query that provokes a bug, the "mini repro" approach is an automated way to reduce the problematic query down to its essential core for easier and quicker bug reproduction.

For consideration: SMT solvers. Problems: quantifier instantiation. triggers. perhaps too tailored towards SMT-LIB benchmarks, therefore not general enough. Qex demonstrates successful use of Z3 to this problem, but: they mention programmatic API, Bjorner, etc (they had 'secret weapons' helping them). (Also: Qex has not been included in Visual Studio yet.)

pluses: 'field tested' in a variety of differing applications. variables in rules/clauses are implicitly universally quantified (in other words, virtually no trouble at all with quantifiers). properties of SLD resolution. history in ATP world.
